Award.AwardTitle: Ligand Control Over Electronic Structure in Metallic Nanoparticles and Model Clusters
Award.AbstractNarration: The Macromolecular, Supramolecular, and Nanochemistry Program in the Chemistry Division supports Professor Benjamin Lear at the Pennsylvania State University to develop new measurement techniques important for tuning various properties of nanoscale metals. In the history of mankind, metals have proven so useful they mark epochs, such as the bronze, iron, and steel ages. Some of the advanced applications of metals in our modern age utilize metal nanoparticles, small metal particles that are 1000 times smaller than the thickness of a human hair. At these scales, the properties of the metals change, giving rise to behaviors that are used to sense and treat cancer, to aid in the production of high-value chemicals, and to eliminate pollutants from the environment. A key challenge in further developing these applications is the measurement of the metal nanoparticles' properties. Professor Learâ€™s team develops new approaches to measuring these properties and then uses these measurements to understand how the chemical environment around metals can be used to tune their activity. In addition to the technical impacts expected in the multidisciplinary areas of chemistry, physics, and materials science, the team brings in high school students from areas across Pennsylvania to participate in various aspects of this research. This project contributes to training these students in modern science as it allows them to make more informed decisions about pursuing careers in science, technology, engineering, and math. <br/><br/>With this support from the Macromolecular, Supramolecular, and Nanochemistry Program in the Chemistry Division, the research team develops new measurement techniques based upon the induced magnetic properties of metals. By applying magnetic fields to nanoparticles, the team can isolate the electronic properties of the metals that are tightly linked to their useful electronic behaviors. Specifically, they use Pauli paramagnetism to study the density of states and the nature of these states near the Fermi energy of the metal. This property controls behaviors such as electrical conductivity and catalytic activity. The team uses both electron spin resonance and nuclear magnetic resonance techniques to achieve these measurements. The team first synthesizes metallic nanoparticles and non-metallic atomically precise clusters, both stabilized by organic ligands at the surface. The team then characterizes the size, shape, and surface chemistry of these nanoparticles. Subsequently, the team measures the electronic and magnetic properties and develops models to account for the influence of the surface chemistry on the measured properties. The end goal is to produce new tools for the scientific community and new insight that can guide the development of applications based upon nanoscale metals.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Metallic nanoparticles (very small bits of metal) are widely used in science and technology, finding applications in areas like medicine and energy production and use. The wide use of these nanoparticles is a result of their desirable electronic properties. This project focused on one specific electronic property known as the 'density of electronic states.' This property, in particular, is strongly linked to behaviors like electrical conductivity, thermal conductivity, and shininess of metals. However, even though this is such a fundamental property, it had proven difficult to measure for nanoparticles systems. The lack of measurement also means that there has been few studies in how to control this property. Gaining a better understanding of how to control this property could increase the already significant utility of metallic nanoparticles. 
Work from the project has established that a relatively inexpensive and widely available scientific technique (nuclear magnetic resonance) can be used to measure this particular property.  Additionally, we have shown that chemicals present at the surface of the nanoparticles can be used to control its value. This is valuable insight, since the means by which these nanoparticles are made often requires the presence of chemicals at the metal surface.  Thus, results from this project demonstrated a means by which to leverage an existing feature of the nanoparticles to control a property that underlies their utility. 
As part of this project, a wide range of metallic systems were examined, including copper, silver, gold, palladium, platinum, and iridium. These are all metals widely used in science and technology, and so show means to tune multiple useful systems, as well as establish the generality of the approach to measuring density of electronic states. 
Beyond looking at multiple metals, models were proposed to explain the influence of the chemicals present at the metal surface, which provides a predictive framework for how the density of electronic states can be rationally tuned. 
Finally, in addition to the impact this work will have on fields using metallic nanoparticles, the work also supported dissemination of materials on the communication of science. These materials can be used by scientists to better communicate the result of their research to each other and to the public. Thus, the project also sought to help other maximize the broader impacts of their work.
